channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2014 The New York Times Company

item.title: Listening Post: Obama Again Tips the Scales Toward Caution on Syria
item.description: At every moment when it has appeared that President Obama might be willing to shrug off his reluctance to act militarily in Syria, he has drawn back.
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: By MARK LANDLER

item.title: U.N. Peacekeepers Locked in Standoff With Syrian Rebels
item.description: A confrontation along the demarcation line between Syria and the Golan Heights occurred a day after an armed group in the area captured 43 peacekeepers from Fiji.
item.dc:creator: By BEN HUBBARD and FLOYD WHALEY

item.title: U.S. Imposes Sanctions on Iranian Groups
item.description: The latest sanctions from the Obama administration come amid signs that Iran’s military is resisting efforts to open up its nuclear program to deeper inspection.
item.dc:creator: By DAVID E. SANGER

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Wang Zhenmin on Hong Kong, Democracy and Protecting the Rich
item.description: In an unusual theoretical leap, a leading Chinese academic said democracy in Hong Kong must be limited in order to protect the interests of its capitalist class.
item.dc:creator: By MICHAEL FORSYTHE and KEITH BRADSHER
item.media:description: Wang Zhenmin, dean of the Tsinghua University School of Law in Beijing.

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: ‘Princess Fragrant’ Mixes Messages on Ethnic Unity, Expert Says
item.description: The cartoon series is said to be aimed at improving ethnic relations, but the show’s Han creators appear to lack cultural knowledge about Uighurs, a visiting scholar has said.
item.dc:creator: By EDWARD WONG
item.media:credit: Gilles Sabrie for The New York Times
item.media:description: Uighur women at a Sunday bazaar in Kashgar.

item.title: Study Says ZMapp Works Against Ebola
item.description: All 18 monkeys exposed to a lethal dose of the virus and given the experimental drug survived, raising hopes that ZMapp will work in people.
item.dc:creator: By ANDREW POLLACK

item.title: Ukraine Rebels Advance on Key Port, in Hint at Putin’s Strategy
item.description: Backed by Russian troops and weaponry, the move by separatists toward Mariupol, the biggest city in the southeast, suggested that President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia wanted to create an overland route to Crimea.
item.dc:creator: By ANDREW E. KRAMER and ANDREW ROTH
item.media:description: President Vladimir V. Putin, arriving at an education forum for students, said the Ukrainian government must enter substantive talks with the rebels.

item.title: Britain Raises Terrorism Threat Level to ‘Severe’
item.description: Alarmed by the suspected presence of hundreds of British jihadis among Sunni militants in Syria and Iraq, the government also said new laws would be introduced to counter security threats.
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: By ALAN COWELL
item.media:description: An armed police officer guards 10 Downing Street in London. On Friday, Britain raised its terrorism threat level to "severe."

item.title: Capture of Soldiers Alarms Russians
item.description: Families appeared to accept the official explanation that the soldiers were lost and not deployed intentionally.
item.dc:creator: By ALEXANDRA ODYNOVA

item.title: New Cabinet, Full of Erdogan Holdovers, Is Announced in Turkey
item.description: The continued presence of Recep Tayyip Erdogan’s appointees at the head of key ministries left little doubt that the president would retain strong influence over the government.
item.dc:creator: By SEBNEM ARSU
item.media:description: Turkey’s prime minister-designate, Ahmet Davutoglu, center, announced a new cabinet on Friday.

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Hong Kong Prepares for Decision on Election Rules
item.description: The territory will learn on Sunday the framework for its next vote for chief executive, including whether and to what extent the candidates will be vetted by a nominating committee.
item.dc:creator: By ALAN WONG
item.media:description: Edward Chin, center, organizer of Financial Professionals for Occupy Central, and Benny Tai, right, co-founder of Occupy Central, at a rally Friday night outside government offices in Hong Kong.

item.title: Relatives of Russian Soldiers Captured by Ukraine Demand Answers
item.description: About 50 women met at a military base to seek information about their loved ones, as Russians began to question the extent of their country’s involvement in Ukraine.
item.dc:creator: By ALEXANDRA ODYNOVA

item.title: A Weary Rebel Retreats From Syria to Fight Another Day
item.description: Kassem Eid, who helped make Moadhamiyeh a symbol of Syrian suffering after government forces blockaded the town in 2012, reluctantly decided to struggle from afar.
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: By ANNE BARNARD
item.media:credit: Michael Appleton for The New York Times
item.media:description: “We have to be honest, we weren’t able to finish it the way we wanted,” said Kassem Eid, a Syrian rebel who has joined the opposition in exile.

item.title: Death Toll in Ukraine Conflict Exceeds 2,200, U.N. Says
item.description: A surge in fighting around Donetsk and Luhansk brought the total number of people killed since mid-April to at least 2,220, and the number of injured to at least 5,956.
item.dc:creator: By NICK CUMMING-BRUCE
item.media:description: A woman passes by the body of a man killed by shelling in Donetsk on Thursday. The United Nations said that casualties had double in the last month.

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Violence at Chinese High School Raises Questions About Mandatory Military Training
item.description: Incoming high school freshmen in China are required to submit to a week of military drills, but several sessions that have gone awry this year have resulted in a storm of criticism on social media.
item.dc:creator: By BECKY DAVIS

item.title: News Analysis: Air Encounter More Likely to Cause Alarm Than Change
item.description: The Pentagon called a Chinese fighter pilot’s approaching an American spy plane “very dangerous,” but the Beijing-Washington division on surveillance flights will probably remain.
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.dc:creator: By JANE PERLEZ
item.media:description: After colliding with a Chinese fighter in 2001, a United States spy plane landed on Hainan island, where a recovery team broke it apart in preparation for its return to the United States.

item.title: Chinese Antigraft Campaign Focuses on a Coal-Rich Province
item.description: Efforts to purge corruption from the Communist Party have reached Shanxi, a province of northern China abundant in coal and opportunities for crooked deals.
item.category: Central Commission for Discipline Inspection (Communist Party of China)
item.dc:creator: By CHRIS BUCKLEY

item.title: Syrian Refugees Surpass 3 Million, U.N. Says
item.description: The relief agency called the crisis “the biggest humanitarian emergency of our era,” as more than a million people have fled in the last 12 months alone.
item.category: United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees
item.dc:creator: By NICK CUMMING-BRUCE

item.title: Heavy Use of Banned Cluster Bombs Reported in Syria
item.description: The Cluster Munition Coalition said the weapons had claimed more casualties in Syria’s civil war than during the denounced deployment of them by Israel in 2006.
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.dc:creator: By RICK GLADSTONE
item.media:credit: Bryan Denton for The New York Times
item.media:description: A cluster bomb was spotted at the Taftanaz air base in Syria after rebels seized the site last year.

item.title: U.S. Identifies Citizens Joining Rebels in Syria, Including ISIS
item.description: Nearly a dozen Americans are known to have traveled to Syria to fight for the Islamic State in Iraq and Syria, the militant group that the Obama administration says poses the greatest threat to the United States since Al Qaeda before the Sept. 11, 2001, attacks.
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: By MICHAEL S. SCHMIDT and ERIC SCHMITT

item.title: Obama Urges Calm in Face of Crises in Ukraine and Syria
item.description: President Obama confronted two volatile crises with restraint Thursday, saying he was not close to authorizing airstrikes in Syria and playing down an escalation of Russia’s intervention in Ukraine.
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: By PETER BAKER

item.title: Over 1,000 Russian Soldiers Join Fight, NATO Says
item.description: Satellite photos released publicly for the first time appear to corroborate NATO assertions that Russian forces are operating in Ukraine territory.
item.dc:creator: By MICHAEL R. GORDON
item.media:description: NATO says this image, which was taken on August 23, shows Russian artillery units in firing position near Krasnodon, Ukraine.

item.title: An Israeli App Tracking the Gaza Conflict Has Followers Near and Far
item.description: More than one million people have downloaded Red Alert, an app tracking rocket fire from Gaza that alerts users with a siren similar to those heard in the south of Israel.
item.dc:creator: By JODI RUDOREN
item.media:description: In Ashkelon, Israel, on Sunday, a woman left the hairdresser’s chair to go to a nearby bomb shelter as sirens rang out. The Hebrew call of “tzeva adom,” or color red, is what is heard by residents in southern Israel in the event of an incoming attack.

item.title: Ukraine Leader Says ‘Huge Loads of Arms’ Pour in From Russia
item.description: President Petro O. Poroshenko of Ukraine said that mercenaries and regular Russian servicemen were trying to overrun positions held by the Ukrainian military.
item.dc:creator: By NEIL MacFARQUHAR and MICHAEL R. GORDON
item.media:credit: Mauricio Lima for The New York Times
item.media:description: A member of a pro-Russian separatist militia walked by an unexploded rocket that fell in the backyard of a house on Thursday in Troitsko-Khartsyzsk, Ukraine.

item.title: With Gaza War, Movement to Boycott Israel Gains Momentum in Europe
item.description: The war in Gaza and its aftermath have inflamed opinion in Europe, analysts say, and are likely to increase support for campaigns to divest from and penalize Israel.
item.dc:creator: By STEVEN ERLANGER
